TranslationsРусскийDevil Town Lyrics[Intro]
Life's alright in Devil Town
We're right, no one's gonna catch us now
Dad has bought a new car now
We're fine, no one's gonna catch us now (Okay)
(Hey!)

[Verse 1]
You said something dumb again
She's mad, at least that's what they say
Mum and Daddy aren't in love
That's fine, I'll settle for two birthdays
[Chorus]
Devil Town is colder in the summertime
I'll lose my mind at least another thousand times
Hold my hand tight, we'll make it another night
I still get a little scared of something new
But I feel a little safer when I'm with you
Falling doesn't feel so bad when I know you've fallen this way too

[Verse 2]
We're all dead in Devil Town
That's fine, 'cause nothing's gonna scare us now
We're all in our dressing gowns, mine's white and stripey
Yours is green and brown

[Verse 3]
I forgot my name again
I think that's something worth remembering
Spiders in your favourite shoes
Just leave them be 'cause they're more scared of you

[Chorus]
Devil Town is colder in the summertime
I'll lose my mind at least another thousand times
Hold my hand tight, we'll make it another night
I still get a little scared of something new
But I feel a little safer when I'm with you
Falling doesn't feel so bad when I know you've fallen this way too

[Outro]
Devil Town is colder in the summertime
I'll lose my mind at least another thousand times
Hold my hand tight, we'll make it another night
I still get a little scared of something new
But I feel a little safer when I'm with you

description.plain: “Devil Town” is Cavetown’s eighth track off of his first E.P, “cavetown”. The song follows the trials and tribulations of a young person’s life, exploring themes of Divorce, Anxiety, and Fear – Experiences many young people can relate to. Also weaved throughout are subtle implications of insanity and mania, and imagery suggests that the young person in question is possibly in some sort of mental asylum: Dressing gowns, forgetting their own name, spiders in shoes, and the actual name of “devil town” all have connotations commonly associated with mental asylums.

song.embed_content: Read “Devil Town” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Devil Town

body.plain: “Devil Town” is Cavetown’s eighth track off of his first E.P, “cavetown”. The song follows the trials and tribulations of a young person’s life, exploring themes of Divorce, Anxiety, and Fear – Experiences many young people can relate to. Also weaved throughout are subtle implications of insanity and mania, and imagery suggests that the young person in question is possibly in some sort of mental asylum: Dressing gowns, forgetting their own name, spiders in shoes, and the actual name of “devil town” all have connotations commonly associated with mental asylums.

songs.title: Cavetown - Devil Town (Русский перевод)

annotations: Dad has bought a new car now
Being financially irresponsible is hinted to be one of the causes of the divorce.

Life’s alright in Devil Town
 We’re right, no one’s gonna catch us now

It’s possible “devil town” refers to a safe space. To get away from the speaker/Robin’s parents, “devil town” is an imaginary place or a name for a real one. He can’t be bothered by his parents fights there.
Hold my hand tight, we’ll make it another night

My mom and my stepdad would fight really bad and my brother and I would hide in my room and hold onto each other.

When you are scared having someone there helps you survive.

Devil Town is colder in the summertime
 I’ll lose my mind at least another thousand times

Even when summer comes, it’s still cold and in comparison, it feels much colder.

Once it’s summer time you don’t have the distraction of school anymore and you’re stuck at home. It’s colder because now you have to actually be face to face with every single fight.

When you are descending into madness, it feels like all these separate things are just you losing your mind a thousand times. You can’t recognize someone’s voice, then you forget what day it is.

I still get a little scared of something new
 But I feel a little safer when I’m with you

Divorce tends to shake a child’s world and make them feel scared or sad, but divorce is common and everyone probably knows at least one person who has gone through it too. Robbie is less scared because he knows others can relate to his experience.

Mum and Daddy aren’t in love
 That’s fine, I’ll settle for two birthdays

Robin’s parents are divorced.

The talk of two birthdays mentions this, and how there will be two of each holiday from now on with his separated parents.

The whole track has an eerie theme of “wrong” or “weirdness,” talking about how it’s “colder in the summertime” or losing our mind. This idea is furthered by the line “two birthdays,” when it’s normal to only have one birthday per year.
Devil Town is colder in the summertime
What Robin means by this is that no matter how warm summer appears, because there isn’t anymore love in his house (because of his parents being divorced), he is cold and sad.

You said something dumb again
 She’s mad, at least that’s what they say
Could refer to parents blaming their children for their fights, or children feeling targeted and that everything they do is wrong (Anxiety).

Spiders in your favourite shoes
 Just leave them be ’cause they’re more scared of you

They haven’t been out in so long that dust has settled in shoes that they used to wear all the time, but now have spiders in them. Because of the fact that they are there (the stigma of what could happen if they go outside), they are now even less willing to leave the house as not to disrupt what has been settled.
I forgot my name again

He has become so disassociated with himself that he forgets things that should come naturally to him. Intended to highlight that sometimes we can get into a state so bad that we don’t even know who we are anymore.

annotations: Or my head
The narrator cannot form their thoughts into words and project them, they are stuck inside their own head.
But I’d miss him in the morning
This shows how used to this ‘sour boy’ (mental illness) that it has almost become a part of him, and he now views it as a section of his life that will be missed.

But I need to understand
 When I can’t power through
 And when I need some help from you

Humans typically believe they are independent, which may greatly boost their ego. However, it isn’t always the case. People might be reluctant to reach out at times. believing they can handle things on their own. In this scenario, that is what is taking place. and when they ultimately decide to reach out. As the issue worsens, it becomes harder to fix.

But I need to understand
 When I can’t power through
 And when I need some help from you

Humans typically believe they are independent, which may greatly boost their ego. However, it isn’t always the case. People might be reluctant to reach out at times. believing they can handle things on their own. In this scenario, that is what is taking place. and when they ultimately decide to reach out. As the issue worsens, it becomes harder to fix.
And a bully in his head
Sometimes our greatest critics are ourselves. This line is talking about the persistent negative thoughts that can make you doubt yourself and your contributions.

Sometimes I act like I know
 But I’m really just a kid

sometimes kids try to seem like an adult and push themselves to know evreything and when adults start talking about serious things we try to act more mature. thats a normal human reaction but at the end of the day dont act like you know evreything and dont try to know evreything you are a kid and if pepole dont understand that then thats there own fault (sorry i kinda deviated from the lryic)
I hope that she looks at me and thinks “Shit, he’s so pretty”
In this line, Robin is praying that the person whom he loves thinks he’s attractive, which he is, but really, he loves all of us, and we all think he’s very pretty because we love him too.
Did I die?

The main character can’t feel anything anymore because of deep depression.
Here he asks if maybe he just died but doesn’t know it yet.
Something I can’t believe
Due to his sadness it’s difficult for him to feel positivity about himself (e.g. think he’s pretty)

I wanna make a colour that no one else has seen before
 I wanna be so much more
He has aspirations that make him want to push past the struggles outlined in the rest of the song. These may be motivations for seeking to understand “when I need some help”.

description.plain:
“Boys Will Be Bugs” is the first track of the split EP Animal Kingdom: Comet.

This song is about the toxic masculinity toward teenage boys that is portrayed in society. Robbie recognizes that he doesn’t fit in with this stereotype. He doesn’t wanna be mean and bully anyone; he just wants to play with bugs.

Robbie’s also known to prefer being friends with girls. This is a theme that shows up during the second verse of the song.
https://twitter.com/CAVETOWN/status/1045301183785693185

annotations:
My mum told me that she’s worried
 And I couldn’t give a shit
Teenagers, especially boys, are expected to be rebellious and not care about consequences, which, in turn, may disturb their parents.
It’s getting cold down here underneath the weather

The phrase “Under the weather”, when attributed to a person, usually means that they are feeling ill.

“It’s getting cold” portrays the narrator as increasingly uncomfortable in this situation.

And I really need a hug
 I feel stupid (Stupid!)
 Ugly (Ugly!)
 Pretend it doesn’t bother me

These lines portray the narrator being self conscious and needing the consolation of a hug but not being able to request this because society views boys as needing to stay strong and not feel the burden(s) of pain.

Just turned fourteen
 And I think this year I’m gonna be mean
This could be in reference to when most people turn of the teenage years they begin going through certain changes, like personality and mood.
I really like your spotty sweater
By “spotty sweater,” Cavetown is referring to the black spots found on ladybugs.
Don’t message me ’cause I won’t reply, I wanna make you cry

Another piece of toxic masculinity is the belief that men shouldn’t be nice to/care about their girlfriends (or wives). This line, especially in conjunction with the next line, shows that the media’s portrayal of masculinity in relationships is impacting how the character feels about them.

What’s it like in a female world?
 I bet it’s just so much better

This is a two-pronged line: Women don’t have to deal with toxic masculinity, making it appear to be the better option, but it also shows teen boys ignorance to the sexism women have to deal with. Sort of a “the grass is always greener on the other side” moment.

Don’t mess with me, I’m a big boy now and I’m very scary
 I punch my walls, stay out at night, and I do karate
 Don’t message me ’cause I won’t reply, I wanna make you cry
 Ain’t that how it’s s’posed to be? Though it isn’t me

He is, in himself, unsure about what he should do. To be accepted into society as a boy, he feels he has to change himself to fit the stereotype. He doesn’t want to do this but thinks it is the only way to be accepted by his peers. He is trying to go with the typical ‘rebellious teenage boy’ act, because he doesn’t know how to become more 3-dimensional and mature from being a ‘boy’ to being a ‘man’, so goes with stereotypical ‘macho man’.

And if you wanna cry
 Make sure that they never see it
 Or even better yet
 Block it out and never feel it

This part is talking about toxic masculinity, people usually tell boys—mainly of younger age—that if a boy cries they are deemed as weak and not fit for society. Making sure nobody sees said character cry is that they don’t want to be judged for seeming weak. To which, the character probably gets paranoid they’d be caught, they decide to bottle up the emotions to not get judged relentlessly of the situation.

This could usually lead to depression, stress and/or anxiety. Depression from bottling up the emotions. Anxiety from the paranoia of getting caught. And, stress from the last two.

Tl;dr
Toxic masculinity that could possibly lead to mental health issues
Though it isn’t me

“Though it isn’t me” means that Robbin just wants to follow in the other “Bugs” (boys) footprints being tiny yet scary though it isn’t him, he just thinks that if he doesn’t want to be picked on or shoved around he has to act like a bug

description.plain:
This song involves a boy singing about being aromantic, as suggested by the line “I cannot fall in love”. He is also asexual and has anxiety, and sings of the troubles/situations he runs into as a result.

The song also describes experiencing gender dysphoria.

Robbie/CAVETOWN is transgender.

annotations: And I’ll figure out a way to get us out of here

This lyric could mean that he is, well, finding a way to escape the wrong body and the “us” is the correct Robbie. It could also be him communicating to those who hear the song saying we aren’t alone and together we can comfortable with our true selves

Get a load of this train wreck
 His hair’s a mess and he doesn’t know who he is yet

This most likely referring to the fact that most closeted trans males will cut their hair short but style it to be feminine leading it to look wrong. Then calling back to his identity crisis, Robin still doesn’t know who he is yet and is stressed that they don’t know, feeling like he has to know right away.

I’m a little sick right now but I swear
 When I’m ready I will fly us out of here

He may be referring to his depression when he says that he is sick, most likely having to do with suicidal thoughts one way or another. Then saying that when he is ready he will be able to escape his thoughts and being free with someone or some people who also are going through the depression or also have suicidal thoughts. Saying that he will help them escape those feelings and thoughts when he is able to do so himself.

By sick, it may not be so physical as a flu, but sick in the head, referring to anxiety, depression, or another mental illness. The person whom Cavetown is promising to ‘get out of here’ may be someone who is losing hope just as quickly, but Cavetown doesn’t want them to give up. “I will /fly/ us out of here'‘ may be referring to angels

Are you dead? Sometimes I think I’m dead
 ’Cause I can feel ghosts and ghouls wrapping my head

It seems as if this is referring to depression; they are losing their touch with reality and they feel nearly unreal, to the point where they’re overwhelmed by “ghosts and ghouls” and so, so tired.

This could elude to depression or a severe case of anxiety where the thoughts may be too voluminous, taking up too much time of the person having the thoughts. As a result, Robin does not feel connected with his reality no longer and he feels as if these thoughts are hunting him, almost.

(Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 I’ll cut my hair
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 To make you stare

He is saying that he will cut his hair for someone to stare at. This might mean that he is finally starting his “escape” from his thoughts, and change his appearance closer to how he sees himself. This likely refers to his transition, since Robbie/Cavetown is transgender.
But I don’t wanna fall asleep just yet

Maybe not wanting to give in to his thoughts or feelings, Robin may not want to metaphorically go to sleep through committing suicide.

He doesn’t seem to want to give into the stress of life, so they are trying not to fall asleep or give up just yet.
But little do we know, the stars

Most likely referring to escaping the pain from the mortal world in order to be part of the sky with the rest of the stars through suicide, Robin is hoping that if he takes this path that the others up there will welcome him with open arms and not shun him.

(Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 My eyes went dark
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 I don’t know where
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 My pupils are
 But I’ll figure out a way to get us out of here

This may allude to the fact he is in the dark and cannot see. Maybe not physical darkness but metaphorical.

Maybe playing by that he can’t see, possibly everything is dark either physically or metaphorically. He may not know where he is due to the darkness.

(Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 I’ll hide my chest

This likely refers to binding his chest due to gender dysphoria, which would be in line with a common theme in the song.

Another meaning can be taken from his music video of “Home,“ a remake of “This is Home.” In it he has a picture book that he flips through with lyrics. When he flips to “I’ll hide my chest” there is a picture of an actual treasure chest, which could symbolize him hiding his “treasure,“ or people and things that he cares about and keeping them “safe” from his mental illness so they don’t get affected by it negatively.

(Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 Time is
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 Slowly
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 Tracing his face
 But strangely he feels at home in this place

Following the analysis of the song being about the transgender community, leaning more towards the trans males, this could very well be talking about how taking testosterone to gain a more masculine voice and appearance or taking estrogen to gain a more feminine voice and appearance, it will take time and it will be slow until he or she is comfortable in their body with the progress they have made with themselves. Saying that in time things will go the way you want it to go and it will show.
“But strangely he feels at home in this place.” This most likely refers to finally reaching how he wants to be, Robin is beginning to look how he wishes to look and is starting to feel right with himself and it’s a foreign feeling for him to be comfortable in his body.

Robbie/CAVETOWN is transgender.

search_results.title: Meteor Shower
search_results.lyrics:
Meteor Shower Lyrics[Verse 1]
I've got miles of regrets and confusing friends
But perhaps it's just my stupid head in the end
Thinking, "Should I wait here or make my way home?"
You said, "Go" (You said, "Go")

[Verse 2]
Making up problems that don't exist
Why do I let myself dream like this?
We're floating away, my body's in space
We are going home
[Chorus]
Missing pieces of my skull
I'll sew on patches of my own soul
There's nothing you or I can do, so let the stars fall
'Cause from up here the sky is my thoughts
And we're all so small

[Verse 3]
Meteor shower, quick, take cover
But the hues in our hair complement one another
I'd sell my own bones for sapphire stones
'Cause blue's your favourite colour

[Chorus]

I'll sew on patches of my own soul

description.plain: The song “Meteor Shower” is about a person and who they love as they go through a metaphorical of a literal meteor shower. The person speaking cares very much about the other and would sacrifice many things for them and says so throughout the song.

song.embed_content: Read “Meteor Shower” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Meteor Shower

body.plain: The song “Meteor Shower” is about a person and who they love as they go through a metaphorical of a literal meteor shower. The person speaking cares very much about the other and would sacrifice many things for them and says so throughout the song.

annotations: Meteor shower, quick, take cover

“Meteor shower” may be referring to a time when he feels his thoughts are raining down and maybe he needs someone to talk to. Thing aren’t looking good on the mental side, and, “Quick, take cover” may be him saying something like “Don’t mind me, I’m okay. Things are fine, worry about other things”
And we’re all so small
This line could mean how insignificant we truly are and how we dont matter
But the hues in our hair complement one another
him and his person have good chemistry and go well with each other

But don’t go outside, it’s dangerous tonight
 Without me right here by your side

This could have something to do with how the singer might be projecting their attachment to this person onto the safety of the outside world. Their anxieties of being abandoned cause them to try and keep the possibility of this person, who is said to be truly important to the singer, from leaving.

’Cause from up here the sky is my thoughts
 And we’re all so small

The speaker’s thoughts are compared to the sky, and since in the song the speaker and their significant other are in a metaphorical meteor shower, it can be inferred that her mind is filled with thoughts pounding down on them, and the two of them are so small compared to everything going on inside their heads.
We’re floating away, my body’s in space

This line has possible connections to disassociation by saying “my bodies in space” when his mind is grounded showing a disconnect. It could possibly be referring to the meteor shower taking place in space and so him being in the meteor showers showing his body being a part of the problems.
Missing pieces of my skull
The reason he is missing peices of his skull is because he gave them to the person so they can “sew up [their] skull”

Missing pieces of my skull
 I’ll sew on patches of my own soul

Robbie references missing pieces of his skull in other songs as well, the common theme most likely referencing his battle with his mind and his mental illnesses such as anxiety and depression. If you’re missing pieces of your skull, your brain is more susceptible to harm.  Sewing on patches of his soul, he uses his energy and personality to try and mend the “holes in his skull”

Making up problems that don’t exist
 Why do I let myself dream like this?

Robbie is making lies and situations that don’t exist to help him feel confident in a way or impress someone, then asking himself why he does that to himself as it is just a cycle of lies and problems he created for saying those lies. Wishing that they did exist for the person he’s trying to impress to truly be impressed

Missing pieces of my skull
 I’ll sew on patches of my own soul
He may feel as though his mind is falling apart, causing him to rapidly attempt to fix it.

description.plain:
“Home” is a remake of Cavetown’s original song “This Is Home.” It was released on June 7, 2019, on streaming platforms, along with the music video released on YouTube.

This is the third version of “This Is Home” that Robbie has released. He uploaded his first remake of the song on YouTube in early 2018.

song.embed_content: Read “Home” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Home

body.plain:
“Home” is a remake of Cavetown’s original song “This Is Home.” It was released on June 7, 2019, on streaming platforms, along with the music video released on YouTube.

This is the third version of “This Is Home” that Robbie has released. He uploaded his first remake of the song on YouTube in early 2018.

songs.full_title: Home (Live at Hoxton Hall) by Cavetown
songs.title: Home (Live at Hoxton Hall)

annotations: Has too many colours, enough to drive all of us insane

This could be referring to pride flags, a set of colourful flags to celebrate the LGBTQIA+ community. A lot of people of the LGBTQIA+ community don’t like their sexuality or gender, or it’s confusing to figure out what it is. That could be the meaning behind “enough to drive all of us insane”.

But little do we know, the stars
 Welcome him with open...
This is a throw at Homophobic and Transphobic people. They always say “you’re going to hell!” and call lgbt members “sinners”, but in fact, heaven welcomes all kind human beings.
I can’t really think right now and this place
the song was written before he transitioned this could allude to Robbie not feeling at home in his body.

But little do we know, the stars
 Welcome him with open arms
The stars refer to people who support him, who welcome him and accept him with open arms.
But strangely he feels at home in this place
This means that someone is finally finding out their gender identity.
I’m a little sick right now but I swear
This could refer to any sickness or perceived “disorder” that Cavetown may have experienced: perhaps depressive episodes, anxiety, or gender dysphoria.

(Mm-mm-mm-mm-mm)
 I’ll cut my hair
 (Mm-mm-mm-mm-mm)
 To make you stare
 (Mm-mm-mm-mm-mm)
 I’ll hide my chest
The reference to cutting his hair and hiding his chest alludes to the narrator being transgender (Which cavetown actually is).

Time is
 Slowly
 Tracing his face

This might refer to the lines you get on your face as you age, or the amount of time that gets wasted daily. This also might refer to him becoming himself, as if he finally as a kind of outline for his personality.
But I don’t wanna fall asleep just yet
This might refer to refuse to giving up fighting depression. Cavetown, like other artists, sometimes uses “falling asleep” as as a reference to dying, as we can see, for example, in “We’re alive”.

(Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 My eyes went dark
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 I don’t know where
 (Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh)
 My pupils are
This might refer to depersonalization, an alteration in the perception of oneself where you feel like you’re not real or your body doesn’t feel real.

I'll help him plant his seeds and we'll mow the lawn in bad weather

description.plain:
Lemon Boy is a character developed by Skinner as a symbol of “the anxiety, the negativity and the illness that’s inside all of us.”

This song explores Robin’s relationship with Lemon Boy and how he affects Robin and his peers, as well as his struggle to learn to live with Lemon Boy.

In an interview with Billboard, Cavetown explained that the title of the track was inspired by lemon boy tomatoes: a hybrid with a characteristic vibrant colour.

song.embed_content: Read “Lemon Boy” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Lemon Boy

body.plain:
Lemon Boy is a character developed by Skinner as a symbol of “the anxiety, the negativity and the illness that’s inside all of us.”

This song explores Robin’s relationship with Lemon Boy and how he affects Robin and his peers, as well as his struggle to learn to live with Lemon Boy.

In an interview with Billboard, Cavetown explained that the title of the track was inspired by lemon boy tomatoes: a hybrid with a characteristic vibrant colour.

songs.full_title: Lemon Boy (Live at Hoxton Hall) by Cavetown
songs.title: Lemon Boy (Live at Hoxton Hall)

annotations: Lemon Boy and I, we’re gonna live forever

This line varies from the previous choruses and the rise in dynamics from the slow, wistful bridge to the upbeat chorus brings a feeling of positivity. However, this could be a false positivity because the fact that they’ll “live forever” implies that he has to deal with his mental health condition for the rest of his life.
I’ll help him plant his seeds and we’ll mow the lawn in bad weather

This line shows his self-destructive behavior as he “helps” to plant the seeds that will grow into mental illnesses He “mows the lawn in bad weather” which will be bad for the grass and the lawn mower, a metaphor for him destroying his own mind. The pronoun “we” implies that he’s not even bothering to fight back at his mental illness and is even helping it along.
Being at piece at a condition that you have is a healthy thing to do, but this line shows that he has stopped fighting it so much that it’s becoming self-destructive.

’Cause we’re the bitterest boys in town
 Yeah, we’re the bitterest guys around
 And I got myself a citrus friend

In the end, he accepts that lemon boy is an important part of himself. He embraces how ‘bitter’ he is, and is okay with that, and learns to love himself. “Yeah, we’re the bitterest guys around”, shows that he’s proud of the bitter boy that he is.
So I got myself a citrus friend
He is still calling his anxiety bitter, but now he’s used to it and cant imagine life without anxiety. Which is common with people with depression as well.
Lemon Boy and me started to get along together
He started to deal with the fact that “Lemon boy” or his anxiety wouldnt leave him alone. So he got used to having him around.
There once was a bittersweet man and they called him Lemon Boy

Lemon Boy is a character created by Robin to represent his insecurities and mental health issues, much like Twenty One Pilots' ‘Blurryface’, or Eminem’s ‘Slim Shady". Here he is described as 'bittersweet’.

bittersweet: sweet with a bitter aftertaste

At first, Lemon Boy may be comforting as Robin knows him, but after a while, he really has a negative impact.
Oh well

After all the what-ifs (a symptom of anxiety in some cases) he just sighs with an “oh well”. This shows kind of a not caring attitude. “So what if Lemon Boy disappears?” is the kind of vibe I’m getting from this line. It could also be him feeling helpless, like, “Oh well, if Lemon Boy disappears what can I do about it?”
It’s actually pretty easy being nice to a bitter boy like him
Here, cavetown is really coming to realize that maybe it really is easier being nice to his mental illness and accepting that it’s there than pretending it’s not and letting it get worse.
So I got myself a citrus friend
This line, however, suggests that he’s getting too familiar with the mental illness, seeing it as a strange kind of comfort.

What if Lemon Boy won’t grow no longer?
 What if beaches dry of sugar cane?

The bridge presents a list of metaphors that describe Lemon Boy disappearing. Beaches drying of sugarcane and a lack of precipitation indicate drought. Water is what is making Lemon Boy grow, and if it is cut off he would perish. These metaphors relate back to the idea of Lemon Boy being a personification of mental illness.

Throughout the song, Robbie has ‘befriended’ mental illness and accepted having it around all the time. The thought of ridding himself of it is terrifying because a part of him leaves, similar to the feeling of losing a close friend.

For most victims of mental illness, the thought of recovering from them is terrifying. These victims could lose a piece of their identity if they consider it to be a defining characteristic.

description.plain: “Fool” is about a boy who is in a toxic relationship with a person who doesn’t love him back. The calming tune combines Cavetown’s smooth vocals, melancholic, and nostalgic lyrics with a feeling of youthful love, but the lyrics tell a different story. By the end of the song, he passes his stages of grief from depression to acceptance. He fully takes in the fact that the relationship was toxic and eventually becomes more aware how much it was hurting him.

song.embed_content: Read “Fool” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Fool

body.plain: “Fool” is about a boy who is in a toxic relationship with a person who doesn’t love him back. The calming tune combines Cavetown’s smooth vocals, melancholic, and nostalgic lyrics with a feeling of youthful love, but the lyrics tell a different story. By the end of the song, he passes his stages of grief from depression to acceptance. He fully takes in the fact that the relationship was toxic and eventually becomes more aware how much it was hurting him.

annotations: Washing machine confuses me

Maybe simple things confuse this person, like a washing machine.  Everyone knows how to use it right? put your clothes in and put in soap then click start, but to this person they are confused about simple things everyone is expected to know for example a washing machine
I don’t know where I’m supposed to go

He feels like everywhere he goes he cannot find anyone who wants to be his friend without anterior motives. He also feels so also alone and that he just wants to escape and find a safe place like “Home”, which is another song that he writes.
(Look in the mirror, I love that boy, don’t hurt my dear, don’t hurt my joy)

This is Robin begging whoever has broken his heart not to hurt him anymore, wether that would be emotionally (his feelings), physically (Abuse), or Mentally (Like his heart being broken).

Another example that they are in a toxic relationship of unreciprocated love and holding on when there is nothing to hold onto. Both being afraid of letting go, instead getting hurt.
Cycling to school at 7:30 in the morning
By sacrificing his sleep for this girl, Robin messes with his sleeping schedule a lot. If he wakes late, he misses the bus, and when you miss the bus, you have to find a different way to school.
I was such a fool to keep on chasing after nothing great

Cavetown restates this lyric, for the purpose of the chorus on one hand, but also to play the role of the character he’s portraying.  This character is a self-aware fool for chasing after someone who either doesn’t love him or doesn’t provide what Cavetown’s character wants otherwise.  The character rephrases this last line by using the past tense “was”, suggesting that the character is beginning to move on and he is finally coming to terms with how what he was “chasing” can never be.

Call me on the phone at three, I talk to you while half asleep
 Complaining ’bout your mother so I take you to the cemetery
 Rant to me, I like the sound, I like your voice, I like your mouth

Robbie is sacrificing a lot for this girl, like his own health. This can also be seen in Robin’s other song, Hug All Ur Friends where he says,
“And I don’t care about my sleeping routine
I fucked it up as it is and we’ve got so much time to kill
As the night rocks me to sleep”
This shows that Robbie is willing to sacrifice himself for those that he cares about.
This also shows that the girl relies on him by ranting to him about her life. While she is doing this, Robin is falling more and more in love with her as she continues talking.
You are just a fool to keep pretendin’ that you’re lovin’ me

Robbie think that it was pointless for her to have been pretending that she / he reciprocated his feelings because in the end, he has realized that the the false love is all it was. False. It just seemed like a large waste of time to him and an unnecessary form of deceit.
Don’t understand my body
“Don’t understand my body” is most likely a reference to his changing from child to man, or the common theory that he does not understand what or who he is a man or a woman.
I am just a fool to keep on chasin’ after nothing great

He feels he was a fool for chasing after a love that is not being reciprocated back to him, the fear of waiting for a standing stone to walk and if it does it won’t walk with him. – This song wasn’t released until later on in Robin’s career as said himself “I also wrote this song back around the same time as ‘It’s U’” he also states that they were “Basically the same” in their meaning. Not stating why this one was only released now.

https://cavetown.bandcamp.com/track/fool

description.plain: This song heavily alludes to an unhealthy crush, even going so far as to be released on Valentine’s Day. In this song Robin describes feelings of inadequacy and needing to please the other person, as well as contrasting the positive imagery of things like “sugar” and “honeydew” with a semantic field of gory imagery like “cavity”, “cardiac”, “skin”, “veins”, “feeling sick”, etc. This juxtaposition creates an uncomfortable feeling that this love interest might not be all good.

song.embed_content: Read “Sweet Tooth” by Cavetown on Genius
song.title: Sweet Tooth

body.plain: This song heavily alludes to an unhealthy crush, even going so far as to be released on Valentine’s Day. In this song Robin describes feelings of inadequacy and needing to please the other person, as well as contrasting the positive imagery of things like “sugar” and “honeydew” with a semantic field of gory imagery like “cavity”, “cardiac”, “skin”, “veins”, “feeling sick”, etc. This juxtaposition creates an uncomfortable feeling that this love interest might not be all good.

annotations:
Think I’ll try to be someone else
 Can’t be hard to paint a person
This line talks about trying to change yourself, most likely to appeal more to someone else, and also, in my opinion, the casual wording of the line conveys how other people make it seem so easy

I’m wide awake
 The sugar went straight to my brain

In these lines, Robbie feels giddy (again alluding to the ‘unhealthy crush’ theme), comparing it to the feeling of having eaten too much sugar. Often those with a ‘sugar rush’ stay awake late and feel hyper because of the high amounts of sugar and energy in their body.
A safety pin
Like a grenade has a safety pin, Robbie is comparing themselves with a grenade, being primed at the start of the relationship ticking down until they explode.
My honeydew
A honeydew is a type of very sweet melon, so by calling this person his honeydew he further emphasizes their sweetness.
It’s filled with scribbles, tore the page

Robbie helped produce the song, “Kindergarten” for his friend Chloe Moriondo. In the music video it shows her getting angry about her crush dating somebody else, (Check it out here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PIs5il5HHyw) and she begins scribbling in her notebook covering up the heart she drew for her. While scribbling, she tears the book page because she’s so full of rage. I think that he added this “easter egg” to get Chloe’s music more recognized. She’s not very widely known, (not to be mean, but i’ve done my research. also i love ur music chloe! and robbie!) and having Robbie mention her might be enough to turn a few heads.
Caught myself blaming planets like you do

At Robbie’s SLC, UT concert, during the VIP session he mentioned how Avery loves Astrology and horoscopes, which Robbie wasn’t interested in at first, but now he’s “blaming planets,” or believing in horoscopes because of Avery.

I like you
 Say it back
 Say it back

Robbie likes this person a lot, and even considering the negative feelings he holds towards himself and the aforementioned confusion he feels when his partner tells him that they love him exactly how he is, he desperately wants to be loved back by them. Whenever this Post-Chorus is delivered, the song slows and quiets down, offering more focus and meaning to these words. It’s as if Robbie is breaking out of his persona for a moment to say outright how he feels. The repetition of “Say it back” is a possible allusion to the fear he holds of losing his partner, and what he would be without them.
While he holds himself in low regards, Robbie holds his partner very highly, and they make him happy. His partner’s praise and reassurance may also be compensating for the lack of positivity Robbie gives himself, and so, the uncertainty of knowing whether or not his partner really does feel that way brings with it an uncertainty that Robbie will have a positive influence in his life.
Another thing of importance to note is the word choice of ‘like’ rather than ‘love’, and the fact that Robbie is asking this question even though his partner has told him already that they love him. This again ties back to Robbie’s self-doubt, especially Verse 1’s line on finding it hard to understand his partner’s perspective – essentially, it may be easier for Robbie to understand that his partner likes him before understanding that they love him.

description.plain: Artist Cavetown, or Robin Skinner, is diagnosed with anxiety disorder. He has made countable videos about his anxiety and various way to deal with it. The song, “Talk To Me,” is about having someone there with you when having a panic attack, or just being anxious. It lists ways to calm down when being anxious and how to be there for someone with anxiety.

body.plain: Artist Cavetown, or Robin Skinner, is diagnosed with anxiety disorder. He has made countable videos about his anxiety and various way to deal with it. The song, “Talk To Me,” is about having someone there with you when having a panic attack, or just being anxious. It lists ways to calm down when being anxious and how to be there for someone with anxiety.

annotations: Even if you run away, you still see them in your dreams
Even though you turn away or ignore your feelings and thoughts they still come back.
It feels like nothing is easy
Sometimes you get so depressed that even functioning is difficult.
It’s so dark tonight, but you’ll survive, certainly
Just because something seems really hard, your life won’t end and things will eventually clear up.

You don’t have to be a prodigy to be unique
 You don’t have to know what to say or what to think
 You don’t have to be anybody you can never be
 That’s alright, let it out, talk to me

some people tend to think that you have to be insanely good at something or be a certain someone  (perfection) to have value in your person and/or in life. in this verse, robin is assuring you that you don’t have to do anything, say anything or be anyone else. you can just be yourself and that no matter what, he’s always there for you to talk to.
It doesn’t make you a narcissist to love yourself

Those struggling with anxiety often put everyone else’s well-being above their own. They are scared to do nice for themselves because they think it will make them appear narcissistic in the eyes of others.
It’s so dark tonight, it looks nice, fall asleep

This lyric directly links to the previous lyric of ‘It’s so dark tonight, but you’ll survive, certainly’ which shows how anxiety and depression can get worse at night as you are left alone with your own thoughts yet it shows that it will be okay. This line reinstates the same meaning yet it comes across more sure and caring as they ensure that the ‘darkness’ that can come from the night through depressive, stressful thoughts looks ‘nice’ allowing the person to feel calmer and ‘fall asleep’.

And the wind it howls and bites
 Bite it back with all your might

Even though the wind is strong, and it’s often cold and “biting” (personified like a wolf), here is a reminder to be stronger than the wind.  Stand up to the feeling of cold doubt, and not only that, use your strength to bite it back.

Because ultimately, the cold wind of doubt is not who you are, and with the strength of a companion, it can be fought back and replaced with reassurance.
It’s alright, come inside, and talk to me

I love the comfort of this final line.  Despite all of his previous songs about being lost and having anxieties of his own, there’s a welcoming voice in this song, inviting the listener to indulge in shared problems and “therapy through music”.

His keen fourth-wall breaking is interesting (and maybe not even intentional!) because of how much his music helps feed and calm the darkness inside us all.  This song is like the musical objectification of a welcoming friend, asking us to stay and talk and work through our problems together.
